And by that mansion's western side there stoode</br>An ancient bowre enwrapte in darkest shade</br>Of sacred elde, and wide-encircling woode;</br>Seemed it was for saintlye abbesse made.</br>Strong were the doors with yron barrs arraide</br>For fear of foe that them enharmen myghte,</br>Ne any durst that fort for to invade,</br>For by the wicket grate, bothe daye and nyghte,</br>A snowy gaurdian sate; of old that Bunny highte.

And all withinne were books of various lore,</br>St. Leon's toils, and Bible nothinge newe,</br>And needle-work, and artists' busie store</br>Of crumbling chalke, and tyntes of everie hue;</br>And on the ground, most terrible to view,</br>Dame Venus' mangled limbs were strewed around;</br>For soothe to tell, the goddess envyous grewe</br>When here she saw myght fairer forms be found,</br>And dash'd in pieces small her statue on the ground.

Such is that bowre, but who shall dare pourtraye</br>What sister fairies there their spells combine;</br>She, whose younge charms the rugged harte cold swaye</br>Of prelate olde, and never tamed divine.</br>She, limneresse of Spenser, (master mine,)</br>Angelic limneresse, in whose darke eye</br>Dothe wit's wilde glance and playful beauty shine</br>And she of shapeliest form and stature highe,</br>And meeke unconscious state and winning majestie.</br>
